results.title: The Barber of Seville by Rossini
results.brief_description: Rossini’s comic opera, sung in Italian. One of a series of “opera-films”, which feature the chorus and orchestra and some of the principals of the Rome Opera House, La Scala, Milan, and other famous Italian opera companies; each film combines scenes from a performance of the opera with an english-language commentary which explains the plot and telescopes the action. Features Tito Gobbi as Figaro.

results.title: The Barber of Seville = Il Barbiere di Siviglia
results.creator_credit: Tespi, Mario Trombetti, Ugo Trombetti and Mario Costa
results.brief_description: Filmed in black and white, this feature length production of Gioacchino Rossini’s comic opera “The Barber of Seville” in three acts, with libretto by Cesare Sterbini and based on the play by Pierre Beaumarchais, was shot in Rome and stars one of Italy’s most famous opera singers, Tito Gobbi, in the role of Figaro the town barber. Figaro is the unsung hero as he ingeniously plots and schemes his way around a love triangle between Count Almaviva (Ferruccio Tagliavini), the young and beautiful Rosina (Nelly Corradi) who the Count madly adores, and Dr Bartolo (Vito De Taranto), Rosina’s strict guardian who also fancies Rosina and wants to make her his wife. It is through Figaro’s amazing disguises and interferences that finally outwit Dr Bartolo, allowing the two lovers to eventually elope. Features the Orchestra and Chorus of the Opera of Rome conducted by Giuseppe Morelli and a supporting cast including Italo Tajo, Natalia Nicolini and Nino Mazziotti. Sung in Italian with no English subtitles. NB: Image quality is inconsistent (particularly in the beginning) and sound track is a bit scratchy but production is of historical value.

results.title: The Barber of Seville = Il Barbiere di Siviglia
results.brief_description: Fast, funny and furious, Rossini’s “Barber of Seville” boasts a torrent of sparkling music, while John Cox’s production adds its own distinctive lustre to this comic masterpiece enhanced by John Rawnsley’s fine comic acting portrayal of Figaro and Maria Ewing’s bewitching Rosina. The London Symphony Orchestra is conducted by the young French conductor, Sylvain Cambreling. Sung in Italian. No subtitles.

results.title: The Bank of England
results.creator_credit: Wessex Productions, Ian Dalrymple and Derek Williams
results.brief_description: Shows the many aspects of the Bank’s life; the traditions and premises, the hierarchy and staff; meetings of the Court and committees; the work of certain departments such as the printing works. An intricate machine and the people who operate it have been skillfully photographed. Includes the Guard, the Sports Club, and the exterior of several branches. Indirectly the historical aspects are portrayed.

results.title: The Bank holiday crisis of 1933
results.creator_credit: Young America Films, James Fonda and William Russell
results.brief_description: In March, 1933, President Roosevelt declared a bank holiday to help the American nation recover from the panic of financial collapse. The situation is shown in scenes in a bank, in soup kitchens and milk lines and in a Salvation Army home in New York. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Banjo and the bard
results.brief_description: A poetic debate between Banjo Paterson and Henry Lawson ran over several weeks in the Bulletin magazine of the 1890s. The subject of the debate was the Australian bush. Paterson, who spent most of his life in more affluent surroundings than Lawson, saw the bush as a place of romance and adventure. Lawson saw only the hardship and struggle. To earn themselves some money they convinced the Bulletin to print the poems they each wrote disclaiming the other’s point-of-view. The story is filmed entirely in contemporary settings with Paterson and Lawson, in their period costume, as the only references to the time-frame of the Bulletin articles.

results.title: The Band concert
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Productions and Walt Disney
results.brief_description: Despite interference from a bee, a noisy Donald Duck playing “Turkey in the Straw”, and a full scale whirlwind, Mickey’s band doggedly performs the “William Tell Overture”. This was the first Mickey Mouse cartoon to use technicolor and is considered to be one of the Disney studios best.

results.title: The Banana story
results.creator_credit: Australia Health Publicity Control Council, Cambridge Film Productions and David Bilcock
results.brief_description: An account of the banana growing industry in northern New South Wales, showing all stages in the growing of bananas; areas of Queensland and New South Wales most suited to banana growing; tree felling and clearing the land; preparation of the ground; planting; pest and disease control; development of the fruit on the plant; picking, grading, packing and transporting the fruit to all states; finally ripening the fruit prior to sale at local markets.

results.title: The Banana splits and friends show
results.creator_credit: Hanna-Barbera Productions, Turner Broadcasting System and Edward Rosen
results.brief_description: Rev up your dune buggies and return to the Banana Pad for one last stand with the crazy Banana Splits - Fleegle, Bingo, Drooper and Snorky! Experience the first three episodes of this groovy 1960s children’s entertainment show. Tune in for your fix of psychedelic performance clips from the Splits and get the vibes from the original cartoons - “The Arabian Knights”, “The Three Musketeers” and the live-action “Danger Island” starring Jan-Michael Vincent. Far out!

results.title: The Bamboo brush (K)
results.creator_credit: Seaton McLean, Michael Macmillan, Janice Platt and Sturla Gunnarsson
results.brief_description: This is a story about a young Chinese-American boy, living in America, and the conflicts that he encounters as a result of the two very different cultures that he is part of. Through his troubles, the boy becomes very close to his Chinese grandfather and after the grandfather’s death, he realises that he has resolved his conflicts.
